newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Mosenergo 1996 GAAP profits leap 56 pct.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Mosenergo 1996 GAAP profits leap 56 pct.

text.p: Russia's biggest regional power company Mosenergo said Monday its net profit rose more than 50 percent in 1996, according to U.S. accounting standards.
But the company made it clear it was prepared to cut off supplies to customers who do not pay their bills -- a common problem in Russia -- even at the cost of lower output.

OAO Energetiki i Elektrifikatsii Mosenergo, which supplies electricity and heating to the Moscow region, saw net profit rise 56 percent to $598 million from $383 million according to U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
Earnings per share rose 44 percent to 23 cents from 16 cents in 1995, while sales rose 41 percent to $4.13 billion.

The figures, audited by international accountancy firm Arthur Andersen, were issued by Mosenergo's financial adviser Salomon Bros. Mosenergo accounts for 10 percent of the electricity produced in Russia.

Russian energy companies are among the biggest victims, as well as the main offenders, in the web of unpaid bills choking the Russian economy. Customers do not pay for their power, and the companies do not pay their energy suppliers in turn.
